title: Two more people arrested over deaths of 39 people in Essex
text:
Police investigating the deaths of 39 people in a lorry have made two more arrests

A husband and wife who are the last known owners of the lorry carrying 39 people who were found dead in Essex are believed to have been arrested.

Joanna Maher and her husband Thomas, both 38, are understood to have been held on suspicion of conspiracy to traffic people and on suspicion of 39 counts of manslaughter.

The pair said they sold the cab a year ago and had voluntarily gone to the police themselves.

The arrests come as detectives were given an extra 24 hours to question Mo Robinson, a truck driver from Northern Ireland.

He was detained after the grim discovery in the back of his refrigerated truck at the Waterglade Industrial estate, near Grays, on Wednesday morning.

Post mortems have now begun on the victims – 31 men and eight women who are from China and Vietnam.

Mo Robinson is being questioned by police after the discovery in the back of his lorry

Police outside the home of Joanna and Thomas Maher who were the previous owners of the lorry (Picture: Peter Powell)

Mrs Maher was revealed as the last-known keeper of the Scania truck that was registered in Bulgaria in 2018.

Cheshire Police were seen at their Warrington home this morning, just before the arrests were announced.

Outside their four-bed detached property were a fleet of expensive cars with private number plates.

She told MailOnline: ‘We did own it but sold it 13 months ago.

‘It’s the cab – my name was down as owning it.’

The couple, originally from Ireland, said they sold it to a company in County Monaghan, close to where Mr Robinson lives.

Mr Maher said he sold it on 3 October last year and said the couple owned it for just a year.

He added: ‘It’s disgusting what’s happened.

‘I went to the British police as we were the registered owners in Bulgaria. I phoned them myself.

‘They were happy we had come forward. They are well aware of who they are dealing with.

‘It’s not nice to be associated with this. We’re shocked.’

Locals said Mr Maher is the owner of a haulage firm and his wife works as a hairdresser.

Police outside the home of Joanna and Thomas Maher who were the previous owners of the lorry (Picture: Peter Powell)

Police outside the home of Joanna and Thomas Maher (Picture: Peter Powell)

The refrigerated part of the lorry is owned by Irish company Global Trailer Rentals Ltd (GTR).

Today, a spokesman said they were ‘shellshocked’ and ‘gutted’ by the news.

The firm said the trailer had been leased on October 15 from its rentals yard in Co Monaghan, in the Republic of Ireland, at a rate of 275 euro (£237) a week.

Advertisement

Advertisement

It said it provided police with information about the person and company that leased the trailer, as well as offering to make tracking data available.

Three addresses have been searched in Northern Ireland as part of the probe, while warrants were also carried out in Cheshire.

Essex Police are still questioning Mr Robinson and have until this afternoon to decide whether to charge or release him.

Speaking of the latest arrests, a force spokesman said: ‘We have carried out warrants in Cheshire as part of the investigation into 39 bodies being discovered in a lorry trailer in Grays.

‘As a result, a 38-year-old man and a 38-year-old woman from Warrington have been arrested on suspicion of conspiracy to traffic people and on suspicion of 39 counts of manslaughter.

‘A 25-year-old man, the driver of the lorry, remains in custody on suspicion of murder’.

A convoy of funeral directors vehicles enter the Port of Tilbury to collect the bodies of the 39 people found inside a lorry in Essex (Picture: PA)

The Waterglade Industrial Park where 39 bodies were found in a lorry container (Picture: Rex)

The police investigation is Britain’s largest murder probe since the 2005 London suicide bombings.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson described Wednesday’s discovery as an ‘unimaginable tragedy’.

Questions have been raised about when the victims entered the refrigerated trailer, where temperatures can be as low as -25C.

There are fears the could have been locked in the freezing trailer for days or suffocated.

Mr Robinson is believed to have driven the tractor unit – the front part – from Northern Ireland over the weekend and collected the trailer late on Tuesday night.

Advertisement

Detectives say the trailer travelled from Zebrugge, Belgium, into the Essex port of Purfleet.

It then docked in the Thurrock area at around 12.30am local time on Wednesday and stopped for around 35 minutes.

CCTV footage shows Mr Robinson driving into the industrial estate at 1.10am and the ambulance service alerted the police around half an hour later.

GPS tracking on the container showed it stopped in Calais and Dunkirk before heading to Zebrugge for the fateful trip to Essex.

The container lorry where 39 people were found dead inside (Picture: PA)

People hold a candlelight vigil for the victims that died in a lorry container (Picture: EPA)

The victims are believed to have mainly come from Fujian, a poor coastal province in south-east China.

Gangsters charge up to £20,000 to smuggle people to the UK via Serbia, Hungary, Austria and France before a boat to the UK.

China has called for joint efforts to counter human smuggling and been critical of tragedies involving its nationals in the UK.

In June 2000, 54 men and women from Fujian were found dead in the back of a tomato lorry which arrived in Dover.

In 2004, 23 Chinese nationals drowned in the Morecambe Bay cockling disaster and they had been trafficked from Fujian.

Human rights campaigners have held vigils in London and Belfast to pay tribute to the victims.
description: A man and a woman, both aged 38 and from Warrington, Cheshire, have been arrested on suspicion of manslaughter and conspiracy to traffic people.
